meanings.definition: Using a part to represent the whole or vice versa.
meanings.sent1: In the story, the author used 'hand' as a synecdochic to represent the entire person.
meanings.sent2: The phrase 'all hands on deck' is a common synecdochic expression.
meanings.sent3: At the bakery, 'fresh bread' was a synecdochic for all the delicious treats available.
meanings.sent4: Her 'silver tongue' was a synecdochic for her persuasive speaking skills.
meanings.sent5: The 'crown' in the painting was a synecdochic for the entire royal family.

meanings.definition: A figure of speech in which a part is used to represent the whole.
meanings.sent1: The term 'suits' is a synecdochic for business executives.
meanings.sent2: When she said 'nice wheels,' she was using synecdochic to refer to the whole car.
meanings.sent3: The phrase 'lend me your ears' is a synecdochic for asking people to listen.
meanings.sent4: His 'new set of wheels' was a synecdochic for his brand-new car.
meanings.sent5: The 'crown' in the play was a synecdochic for the entire kingdom.
